title: Agile Principles & Values
description: Master the 4 Agile Manifesto values, servant leadership, collaboration techniques (swarming, mobbing, pairing), limit WIP, and the Agile mindset shift from command-control.
objectives: Apply the 4 Agile Manifesto values to decide when Agile is appropriate
Distinguish servant leadership (remove impediments, coach) from command-control leadership
Use Agile collaboration techniques (swarming, mobbing, pairing) to resolve team impediments
Apply limit WIP, fist-of-five consensus, and retrospectives for continuous improvement
Recognize flexibility and adaptability as the core Agile characteristics

screens.headline: The team wants a detailed 3-month plan. Taylor says: 'We'll plan 2 weeks at a time.' Carlos confronts: 'You're not leading—you're just facilitating!' Chaos or brilliance?

items.label: Traditional
items.detail: Gantt chart, manager pointing at tasks, team waiting for orders

items.label: Agile
items.detail: Team self-organizing around kanban board, collaborating, iterating on prototypes

dialogue.text: Agile isn't chaos—it's DISCIPLINED FLEXIBILITY. Command-control kills creativity. Servant leadership empowers teams. Let Taylor show Carlos a better way.

screens.learningHook: Agile is a MINDSET shift, not just a process. Learn: 4 Agile Manifesto values, servant leadership, swarming, and limiting WIP.

screens.title: Agile Mindset Challenges
screens.instructions: For each challenge, select the Agile principle/practice AND Taylor's best response.

scenarios.title: Command-Control Mindset
description: Week 1 standup. Taylor asks: 'What are you working on today?'
Maya: 'We don't know—aren't YOU supposed to tell us? That's what Carlos always does.'
Everyone waits for Taylor to assign tasks.

questions.question: Which Agile principle addresses this challenge?

options.text: Individuals and interactions over processes and tools
Responding to change over following a plan
Servant Leadership—Remove impediments, empower team (not command)
Working software over comprehensive documentation

feedback.correct: Servant leadership empowers teams to self-organize. Leaders remove impediments and coach—they don't dictate tasks.
feedback.incorrect: This is about LEADERSHIP STYLE. Servant leadership means empowering the team, not commanding.

options.text: Assign tasks to each person to get them started
'What's the most valuable thing we can deliver this sprint? Who wants to work on what?'
Tell them to figure it out themselves—it's their responsibility
Create a detailed task list for the team to pick from

feedback.correct: Empowering question transfers ownership to the team. Servant leadership guides and coaches—doesn't dictate or abandon.
feedback.incorrect: Servant leaders ASK empowering questions, not assign tasks (commanding) or abandon ('figure it out' = abdication).

scenarios.title: Paralysis by Perfect Planning
description: Week 2. Team refuses to start cooking. Devon: 'We need a COMPLETE specification first—all ingredients, suppliers, pricing.'
Taylor: 'Let's create ONE prototype dish this week and get customer feedback.'
Carlos agrees with Devon: 'Plan first, execute second.'

questions.question: Which Agile value addresses this challenge?

options.text: Responding to change over following a plan
Customer collaboration over contract negotiation
Working software over comprehensive documentation
Individuals and interactions over processes and tools

feedback.correct: 'Responding to change over following a plan' means embracing uncertainty—refine based on feedback, don't predict everything upfront.
feedback.incorrect: The team wants perfect planning. Agile says: Embrace change, iterate based on feedback.

options.text: Agree: Spend 2 weeks creating a detailed specification
'We'll use iterative approach—cook a prototype, get feedback, refine. Uncertainty is expected.'
Compromise: Create a 1-week mini-plan, then iterate
Tell them to start cooking without any planning

feedback.correct: Iterative approach: prototype → feedback → refine. Learn more from ONE real prototype than 2 weeks of theoretical planning.
feedback.incorrect: Agile embraces uncertainty through iteration. Don't wait for perfect plans—prototype, learn, adapt.

scenarios.title: Solo Work Culture
description: Week 3 standup. Maya mentions: 'I've been stuck for 2 days trying to source an ingredient—supplier says unavailable.'
She doesn't ask for help. Plans to keep struggling alone.
The rest of the team moves on.

options.text: Swarming/Mobbing—Multiple team members rally to resolve the impediment together
Pairing—Assign ONE other person to help Maya
Retrospective—Discuss the issue at the end of the sprint
Fist of Five—Vote on whether to help Maya

feedback.correct: Swarming: Multiple team members rally to resolve blockers IMMEDIATELY. Don't leave someone stuck alone for days.
feedback.incorrect: Maya is blocked NOW. Retrospectives address PAST issues at sprint end. Swarming addresses CURRENT blockers immediately.

options.text: 'Keep trying. Let me know if you're still stuck next week.'
'Maya's blocked. Who can swarm this with her RIGHT NOW? Let's resolve it today.'
Assign one person to help Maya, continue standup
Take the task from Maya and reassign it to someone else

feedback.correct: Swarm immediately: 'Who can help RIGHT NOW?' Team rallies to remove impediment together. Don't leave blockers unaddressed.
feedback.incorrect: Agile teams remove impediments TOGETHER. Swarming means multiple people rally immediately—don't wait until next week.

scenarios.title: Too Much Work In Progress
description: Week 4. Taylor reviews the board: Everyone is working on 4-5 tasks simultaneously.
Nothing is moving to 'Done.' Maya juggling 3 dishes, Devon designing 4 plates.
Carlos: 'Great! Everyone's busy!' But Taylor notices: NO completed work.

options.text: Limit Work In Progress (WIP)—Focus on completing 1-2 items before starting new work
Add more team members to handle the workload
Extend the sprint to allow more time
Increase standup frequency to 2x/day

feedback.correct: Limit WIP: Stop starting, start finishing. High WIP = context-switching, delays, nothing finishing. Constrain WIP to improve flow.
feedback.incorrect: Problem isn't headcount or time—it's multitasking. Limiting WIP improves completion rate and focus.

options.text: 'Everyone's busy, this is fine. Keep multitasking.'
'We need to LIMIT WIP. Each person: finish your #1 priority before starting anything new.'
Cancel the sprint and restart with clearer priorities
Ask team to work overtime to finish everything

feedback.correct: 'Stop starting, start finishing.' Limit WIP to 2 items/person. Completion rate DOUBLES when you stop multitasking.
feedback.incorrect: High WIP = low completion rate. Solution: Limit WIP. 'Finish #1 priority before picking up new work.'

values.meaning: Empower people to solve problems creatively
Deliver functional increments, get feedback, iterate
Ongoing partnership with customers, not rigid contracts
Flexibility and adaptation, not fixed predictions

content.note: The Manifesto says: 'While there is value in the items on the right, we value the items on the left MORE.' It's prioritization, not either/or.

characteristics: Serves team members, assists in their growth
Focuses on removing impediments and providing resources
whatItIsNot: NOT taking instructions FROM the team (leader still accountable)
NOT abdicating responsibility ('you figure it out')
content.pmbokRef: PMBOK 7th Ed pages 17-18; Agile Practice Guide page 33

practices.name: Swarming/Mobbing/Pairing
practices.definition: Team members rally together to resolve impediments immediately

practices.name: Limit WIP
practices.definition: Constrain how many tasks are in progress. Finish before starting new work.

practices.name: Fist of Five
practices.definition: Voting technique (0-5 fingers) for consensus. 3+ = proceed.
practices.use: Team alignment without forcing unanimous agreement

practices.name: Retrospectives
practices.definition: End-of-iteration meeting: What went well? What needs improvement?

practices.name: Iterative & Incremental
practices.definition: Iterative = successive prototypes (learning). Incremental = small functional deliveries (value).

insights.insight: Flexibility & Adaptability are THE most important Agile characteristics
insights.explanation: All other skills can be learned. Without flexibility, Agile fails.

insights.insight: Servant leadership does NOT mean taking instructions from the team
insights.explanation: Leaders empower and coach, but remain ACCOUNTABLE. Facilitate, don't become order-takers.

insights.insight: Re-engage stakeholders with working increments + value their feedback
insights.explanation: Show tangible progress early and often. Demonstrate how their input shaped the product.

insights.insight: Agile focuses on high-priority tasks, NOT on predicting all work upfront
insights.explanation: Ask: 'What's the highest value we can deliver NOW?' Prediction is de-emphasized.

correct.text: I thought servant leadership meant weakness. But Taylor asking 'What do you want to work on?' transferred ownership to the team. They're more engaged than when I micromanaged them.
Week 5 update: I finished 4 tasks by focusing on one at a time. Before, I was juggling 5 and finishing zero. Less multitasking = MORE output.

screens.title: Convince Carlos: Disciplined Flexibility
screens.context: Carlos admits the team is more productive but says: 'From the outside, it LOOKS like chaos. How is this better than command-control?'

questions.question: Classify each Agile practice: DISCIPLINED or CHAOTIC?

pairs.item: Daily standups at the same time every day
No deadlines - work whenever inspiration strikes

questions.question: Complete: 'Agile isn't chaos—it's __________. We have predictable delivery through Sprints, daily accountability through standups, and continuous improvement through retrospectives.'

options.text: complete chaos
disciplined flexibility

screens.title: Agile Mindset Mastery
screens.summary: You've learned the Agile mindset: prioritize people and interactions, working solutions, customer collaboration, and responding to change. You've applied servant leadership, swarming, limiting WIP, and iterative feedback.
takeaways: Agile Manifesto: Individuals/interactions > processes, Working product > documentation, Collaboration > contracts, Change > plan
Servant leadership empowers and coaches—doesn't command or abdicate
Swarming: Team rallies to remove impediments immediately (don't leave people stuck)
Limit WIP: Stop starting, start finishing—improves completion rate and flow
Flexibility & Adaptability are THE most important Agile characteristics
Agile is DISCIPLINED FLEXIBILITY, not chaos

artifacts.title: Agile Manifesto & Practices Reference
artifacts.description: 4 Manifesto values, servant leadership checklist, collaboration techniques, WIP limits

characterClosing.text: I've managed teams for 20 years using command-control. In 5 weeks, Taylor showed me a better way. Agile isn't chaos—it's disciplined flexibility. I was wrong.

nextLesson.teaser: Now that you understand the Agile mindset, learn WHEN to use Agile vs predictive approaches based on project characteristics.
